docs.abstract: Jason Epstein article on Russ & Daughters, premiere New York food emporium that spawned Zabar's and others; recipes for classic chopped chicken liver, smoked salmon tartare and mushroom-barley soup; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: When I walk the mile or so from my apartment in SoHo to Russ & Daughters on East Houston Street near Orchard, on Manhattan's suddenly stylish Lower East Side, I experience that enlargement of the soul felt by ancient worshipers as they blissfully approached the temples of their gods. Russ & Daughters is not a mere seller of ''appetizers,'' as Joel Russ's sign has proclaimed ever since he founded his business in 1914. It is New York's most hallowed shrine to the miracle of caviar, smoked salmon, ethereal herring and silken chopped liver. It is the mother church of those latter-day temples -- Zabar's, Barney Greengrass and Murray's Sturgeon Shop -- that dot the Upper West Side and serve the great-grandchildren of Joel Russ's original customers.

docs.abstract: Jonathan Reynolds article on joys of classic malted milkshakes and other foods prepared with malt; recipes; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Of the four most perennially puzzling culinary mysteries -- how do you cook perfect rice consistently, who separates the juice of the pomegranate from its seeds, what the hell is in marshmallows and where did my malted milk go -- the only question I can answer with any authority is the last. Like Nesselrode pie and Danish pudding, Judge Crater, Salinger's talent and the friendship between Woody and Jean, malted milk has disappeared. Well, almost. (But then, the same possibly can be said for Judge Crater.) Nothing conjures the small-town America of Andy Hardy, Thornton Wilder and Norman Rockwell like a malted milkshake served in a carbuncular soda glass and blissfully slurped through a straw -- unless perhaps it is the four-fingered baseball mitt or the blueberry-apple pie cooling on that Kansas windowsill. I don't know if there's actually malt in all the Rockwell shakes or in the famous drugstore scenes from ''Our Town'' and ''Shadow of a Doubt'' or when Andy and Polly roll their eyes at each other, but I'd like to think there is, because those blessed drinks sure seemed to mollify the hyperactive and to bring families close.

docs.abstract: Jonathan Reynolds article rejoices in properly prepared pork chops; advocates brining to ensure tender, delicious chop; recipes; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Why are today's pork chops so bad? Dry, mealy, sturdy as medieval armament. Didn't used to be. Those who knew how to cook them back in the day released their subtle flavor, tenderness and juice by simply sautéing or grilling them quickly till they were nicely pink inside and had reached a temperature of 137 degrees Fahrenheit -- the point at which the government decreed that trichinosis is killed. Still, plenty of childhoods were spoiled with knife-breaking chops, as paranoid chefs and mothers cooked them beyond the Frank E. Campbell stage and well into cremation range. (Cookbooks often suggested that though 137 did kill the trichinosis, you should add a few degrees to be safe, and the ''to be safe'' limit mushroomed from 137 to 160 to 170. The old ''Joy of Cooking'' suggested 185.) But when not overcooked, there was nothing like them. Then in the late 70's, the saturated-fat police broke down the door, and pork sales declined as the country went mad for pasta and bread and something frighteningly called ''legumes.'' And the truth was, pork may have contained as much if not more bad fat than beef and lamb, and much more than the newly canonized icon of victual virtue, skinless white chicken meat. Such was the fevered belief in the fat-free religion that intimidated cooks seldom argued how numbingly boring that skinless chicken meat was -- hence the billions of recipes needed to enhance its flavor. In a Kubrickian twist, the goo needed to enliven chicken often turned out to add more fat to the dish than if you had prepared a slobbering old prime rib in the first place.

docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant Food column offers winter salads using frisee, bacon, potatoes, pesto and egg and other ingredients; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: SALAD in winter can take imagination. It's not the moment for that wonderful bunch of freshly picked arugula and ripe tomatoes that shine with but a splash of good extra-virgin olive oil. The greens, when they're not limp, may be sturdier, and the tomatoes are either dismal or require a bank loan to buy them. There are suitable alternatives that can have enough heft to be a free-standing first course. One of my favorites is the French combination of frisée, a kind of tender, baby chicory, with nuggets of bacon in a warm bacon dressing and a poached egg on top. Another salad uses crisp fennel, its anise flavor an excellent foil for mushrooms, walnuts and Parmesan. A third adds potatoes and a quick parsley pesto to bolster a simple romaine lettuce salad.

headline.main: Bacon, Frisée or Pesto for Salads With Summer Envy

docs.abstract: Food column on methods for oven-cooking fish; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THICK fillets of fish are easy to cook in the oven. They can be seared in a nonstick pan or poached in olive oil in a baking dish. Cod, halibut, turbot, bass or salmon are good prepared this way, and emerge juicy and moist. You can use all manner of herbs including parsley, thyme, rosemary and oregano to flavor the fish. Slices of lemon can be cooked underneath it. The lemon loses its harshness and comes out soft and sweet. A new way of cooking fillets is to poach them in olive oil, in the same way that duck is poached in its own fat to make a confit. The fish is not oily and can be served plain with a little of its cooking oil sprinkled over it. The oil can also be made into a vinaigrette served with the fish or another dish. It doesn't pick up a fishy taste after it has been used to poach the fish. But it should be used within a week.

headline.main: Variations Make Oven-Cooked Fish Succulent and Exciting

docs.abstract: Moira Hodgson Food column offers recipes for braised, deep-fried and sauteed artichokes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: JUST as the summer harvest fades, artichokes are back on the scene. When I was growing up, we only had them two ways: hot, with hollandaise, or cold, with mayonnaise. Each leaf was savored until you got down to the best part: the heart, or bottom. Now, however, I prepare artichokes so many other ways that I rarely cook them whole. I can even discard the leaves without feeling guilty about wasting the piece of flesh at each base. I braise artichokes in white wine, deep-fry them or serve them in raw, paper-thin slices sprinkled with olive oil and lemon. Slivered and fried, the baby ones make a lovely topping for a stew. Cut into wedges, they are delicious sauteed with other vegetables, like Florence fennel, carrots or potatoes.

docs.snippet: Nathan Myhrvold's kitchen is so advanced that it requires a Ph.D. and welder's mask....
docs.lead_paragraph: As he showed me around his best-equipped-in-the-universe kitchen, I half-expected Nathan Myhrvold to introduce himself as ''Bond, James Bond.'' Myhrvold, the 46-year-old former chief technology officer for Microsoft, left the the company in 2000 with well over $100 in his pocket in order to roam the world with his wife and twin teenage boys. Along the way he became the most professional nonprofessional foodista I know. He not only hobnobs with great chefs (42-course dinner in Ferran Adrià's kitchen) but is also one himself.

docs.abstract: Comment on nutritional requirements of Olympic class athletes; description of weight lifter Shane Hamman's 5,000-calorie-a-day diet, synchronized swimmer Anna Kozlova's 2,500-calorie diet, and triathlete Hunter Kemper's 5,000-calorie diet; photos (L)

byline.original: By Maura Egan and Christine Muhlke

docs.lead_paragraph: SHANE HAMMAN (Weight Lifter) Shane Hamman, the No. 1 weight lifter in America, placed in the Top 10 in the Sydney Olympics by lifting 926 pounds. The 32-year-old is the best in snatch, clean and jerk and total weight lifting. (He can squat more than 1,000 pounds; clean and jerk 518.) With his trademark braid dangling from his chin, Hamman stands out in the weight room, his 35-inch thighs, 44-inch waist, 22-inch neck and 62-inch chest reflecting the 5,000 protein-heavy calories he consumes each day for muscle building. ''To eat that much, I eat what tastes good, because I got to eat it,'' he says. Not even the Olympic training-center cafeteria can keep up with his intake: every night in his room he cooks his own dinner, two massive cheeseburgers, and bakes chocolate-chip cookies.
